item.title: Remove
item.dc:creator: @Killed_By_Squirrel Killed By Squirrel
item.description:
@Killed_By_Squirrel wrote:

ownedu1:

ok so will i always put a } beneath it

Nope that closes off the whole void. You would just add another globalobject under it without the bracket. So it would look like this

public void NewObjects() { makeGlobalObject(2999, 3383, 2469, 0, 10);//portal makeGlobalObject(####, ####, ####, #, ##); }

Read full topic

@Killed_By_Squirrel wrote:

ownedu1:

you mean in the ()'s or below it

Below it. Like for Eh’s example it would look like this

public void NewObjects() { makeGlobalObject(2999, 3383, 2469, 0, 10);//portal }

item.title: Remove
item.dc:creator: @Killed_By_Squirrel Killed By Squirrel
item.description:
@Killed_By_Squirrel wrote:

[quote=“ownedu1, post:4, topic:111871”]ok heres some of the code when i search public void newobjects or whatever it is

[code] public void NewObjects() {

}
    public void ChangeDoor(int ArrayID) {
	int objectID = server.objectHandler.ObjectOriID[ArrayID];
	int objectX = server.objectHandler.ObjectX[ArrayID];
	int objectY = server.objectHandler.ObjectY[ArrayID];
	int Face = server.objectHandler.ObjectFace[ArrayID];
	int Type = server.objectHandler.ObjectType[ArrayID];
	ReplaceObject2(objectX, objectY, -1, -1, 0);
	switch (Type) {
		case 1:
			ReplaceObject2(objectX, (objectY + 1), objectID, Face, 0);
			server.objectHandler.ObjectType[ArrayID] = 2;
			break;
		case 2:
			ReplaceObject2(objectX, (objectY - 1), objectID, Face, 0);
			server.objectHandler.ObjectType[ArrayID] = 1;
			break;
		case 3:
			ReplaceObject2((objectX + 1), objectY, objectID, Face, 0);
			server.objectHandler.ObjectType[ArrayID] = 4;
			break;
		case 4:
			ReplaceObject2((objectX - 1), objectY, objectID, Face, 0);
			server.objectHandler.ObjectType[ArrayID] = 3;
			break;[/code]

so where would i place the object i want[/quote]
Right in the NewObjects void.

Read full topic

item.title: Remove
item.dc:creator: @ownedu1 ownedu1
item.description:
@ownedu1 wrote:

ok heres some of the code when i search public void newobjects or whatever it is

[code] public void NewObjects() {

}
    public void ChangeDoor(int ArrayID) {
	int objectID = server.objectHandler.ObjectOriID[ArrayID];
	int objectX = server.objectHandler.ObjectX[ArrayID];
	int objectY = server.objectHandler.ObjectY[ArrayID];
	int Face = server.objectHandler.ObjectFace[ArrayID];
	int Type = server.objectHandler.ObjectType[ArrayID];
	ReplaceObject2(objectX, objectY, -1, -1, 0);
	switch (Type) {
		case 1:
			ReplaceObject2(objectX, (objectY + 1), objectID, Face, 0);
			server.objectHandler.ObjectType[ArrayID] = 2;
			break;
		case 2:
			ReplaceObject2(objectX, (objectY - 1), objectID, Face, 0);
			server.objectHandler.ObjectType[ArrayID] = 1;
			break;
		case 3:
			ReplaceObject2((objectX + 1), objectY, objectID, Face, 0);
			server.objectHandler.ObjectType[ArrayID] = 4;
			break;
		case 4:
			ReplaceObject2((objectX - 1), objectY, objectID, Face, 0);
			server.objectHandler.ObjectType[ArrayID] = 3;
			break;[/code]

so where would i place the object i want

item.title: Remove
item.dc:creator: @Killed_By_Squirrel Killed By Squirrel
item.description:
@Killed_By_Squirrel wrote:

Yes, 0 means the direction it faces. But you may want to know that. Like if you were going to place an altar somewhere, and you wanted to turn it into the direction you desire. Here’s the facing direction numbers you put in place of the 0 every time you add a global object.
0= WEST, -1 = NORTH, -2 = EAST, -3 = SOUTH

Read full topic

item.title: Remove
item.dc:creator: @Eh_Pretty_Easy Eh Pretty Easy
item.description:
@Eh_Pretty_Easy wrote:

Let’s see…public void NewObjects() { search for that then you there should be AddGlobalObject( or makeGlobalObject( under it. I’ll show you an example. AddGlobalObject(2999, 3383, 2469, 0, 10);//portal When you spawn a object, you put the void name infront of everything else, depending on which void you added (AddGlobal or makeGlobal, doesn’t really matter) after that comes the coordinates. The ‘2999’ is the X coordinate, and the ‘3383’ is the Y coordinate and after them is the object ID for a portal in this case 2469. That 0 means the way the object faces, don’t mind about it and the 10 is the height level if I remember correctly. So when you want to add a new object, you just add this inside the public void NewObjects: AddGlobalObject(XXXX, YYYY, ID, 0, 10);//whatever and fill it with the coords and ID you want. I hope I managed to explain something.

Read full topic
